data.title: Hanover Insurance Q4 Operating Income, Revenue Rise
data.description:
Hanover Insurance Group reported Q4 operating income late Tuesday of $5.32 per diluted share, up from $3.13 a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $3.36.

Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 rose to $1.58 billion from $1.53 billion a year earlier.

Two analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $1.61 billion.

data.title: Simulations Plus Insider Sold Shares Worth $678,243, According to a Recent SEC Filing
data.description:

data.title: Mattel Relying on Supply Chain, Potential Price Increases to Offset Tariff Impacts — Update
data.description:
By Connor Hart

Mattel is taking steps to limit the effects of President Trump's proposed tariffs, including relying on its global supply chain and potentially raising prices.

The maker of Hot Wheels cars and Barbie dolls expects such measures to contribute to higher profits and revenue this year.

Chief Executive Ynon Kreiz said that the company has spent years building out a supply chain that isn't overly reliant upon any one country, a structure that will play a critical role in navigating the looming trade war sparked by Trump's proposed tariffs on goods from Canada, Mexico and China.

"We source product today from a mix of our own factories and third-party suppliers in seven different countries," he said Tuesday. "This model is about having a diverse, flexible supply chain that is agile and can respond to different market conditions from different geographies."

Mattel has said it plans to have no singular country account for more than a quarter of its total productions by 2027. Mexico accounts for less than 10% of the company's global production, and it produces less than 40% of its toys in China, whereas the industry average is around 80%, Kreiz said.

The company will also consider increasing its prices, Kreiz said, planning to assess the market as the proposed tariffs play out and adapt accordingly.

Companies have been scrambling to adjust their operations in the wake of the Trump administration's plans to impose tariffs. Automakers, for instance, have searched out new suppliers and have considered higher prices to offset the blow from looming tariffs on Canadian and Mexican imports.

Mattel's sales and profit forecast for the current year came in ahead of what analysts expected, according to FactSet. It also follows better-than-expected fourth-quarter results, during which Kreiz said the toy industry stabilized and U.S. consumers were in a good place.

Shares of Mattel rose 7% in late trading to $19.33. Through Tuesday's close, the stock had been up 1.9% over the past year.

The El Segundo, Calif.-based company reported a profit of $140.9 million, or 42 cents a share, in the recent quarter, compared with $147.3 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier

Adjusted per-share earnings came in at 35 cents, beating the 20 cents that analysts surveyed by FactSet were expecting.

Revenue increased 1.6% to $1.65 billion, just ahead of the $1.63 billion that analysts had forecast.

Among its main brands, Barbie posted a 14% drop in gross billings, which measures sales to retailers before adjustments. The loss was offset by a 15% increase for Hot Wheels and a 3% raise for Fisher Price.

Kreiz attributed Barbie's decline largely to last year's results having been inflated due to the blockbuster "Barbie" movie. He forecast continued momentum across the company's Hot Wheels brand in the current year, in part citing recent partnerships with Formula One and Ferrari.

For 2025, Mattel expects net sales to grow 2% to 3%, which comes after sales fell 1.1% last year. Analysts surveyed by FactSet modeled revenue of $5.5 billion, representing a 2.3% increase from 2024.

The company guided for adjusted per-share earnings between $1.66 and $1.72, ahead of the $1.57 that analysts are looking for.

Write to Connor Hart at connor.hart@wsj.com

data.title: Alphabet Revenue Misses Expectations. The Stock Is Down Sharply. — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Angela Palumbo

Alphabet earnings beat Wall Street expectations, but revenue missed the mark.

Alphabet reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.15 a share on revenue of $96.47 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet were expecting the Google parent to post earnings of $2.13 a share on revenue of $96.68 billion.

In the same period last year, Alphabet reported earnings of $1.64 a share on revenue of $86.3 billion.

Cloud revenue in the quarter of $12 billion — a 30% increase from last year — just missed analyst estimates of $12.2 billion. This comes after Microsoft said on Jan. 29 that revenue in the second quarter from Azure and other cloud services increased by 31%, compared with 33% one quarter earlier.

Youtube offered a bright spot for the company. Its advertising revenue of $10.47 billion beat estimates of $10.23 billion. Meta Platforms also reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter ad-revenue on Jan. 29.

Similarly to fellow tech peers, Alphabet is spending significantly on generative artificial intelligence initiatives. The company reported capital expenditures in the quarter of $14.28 billion, above Wall Street's estimate of $13.26 billion and an increase from the $11 billion last year.

CFO Anat Ashkenazi said on the company's earnings call that most of these investments were towards technical infrastructure, with the largest component being investments in servers and data centers.

"We are confident about the opportunities ahead, and to accelerate our progress, we expect to invest approximately $75 billion in capital expenditures in 2025," CEO Sundar Pichai said in the earnings release.

Shares of Alphabet were down 7.9% in after-hours trading following the report.

Massive spending on generative artificial intelligence has been a continuing theme. However, viral social-media posts last week said that DeepSeek had developed an AI model similar to OpenAI's ChatGPT for significantly less money than what U.S. tech companies have spent on AI. Experts have since decided the cost likely was higher than what has been reported, but there are still those who question whether tech giants need to keep spending as intensely as they have been.

On top of clarification on the expected AI investments for next year, shareholders wanted to get updates about Alphabet's competitive stance. Google has remained king of search for years, but generative AI-powered chatbots have put its market share at risk. On top of ChatGPT and Meta AI, DeepSeek's chat model directly competes with Google's Gemini. Google announced Gemini 2.0 Flash in December, which has faster response times than its predecessor.

When asked about his thoughts on the DeepSeek developments, Pichai said that while DeepSeek's team is "tremendous," and doing "very good work," Google's models "are some of the most efficient models out there, including comparing to DeepSeek's V3 and R1."

Looking ahead, investors are awaiting updates on the Department of Justice's antitrust case.

A judge ruled in August that Google maintained a monopoly in general search services and general text advertising. The Justice Department has suggested a breakup of the company as a potential remedy.

Write to Angela Palumbo at angela.palumbo@dowjones.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Ibiden to Cut Cross-Shareholdings by Over 50% to Boost Capital Efficiency
data.description:
Ibiden plans to reduce its cross-shareholdings by more than 50% on a market value basis by March 31, 2024, under its medium-term management plan, according to a Tuesday filing on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

The move aims to enhance liquidity and capital efficiency. Proceeds will be allocated to strategic investments, business strengthening, and shareholder returns.

data.title: ChampionX Corp reports results for the quarter ended December 31 - Earnings Summary
data.description:
• ChampionX Corp reported quarterly adjusted earnings of 50 cents​​ per share for the quarter ended December 31, higher than the same quarter last year, when the company reported EPS of 44 cents. The mean expectation of seven analysts for the quarter was for earnings of 49 cents per share. Wall Street expected results to range from 39 cents to 59 cents per share.

  • Revenue fell 3.3% to $912.04 million from a year ago; analysts expected $913.61 million.

  • ChampionX Corp's reported EPS for the quarter was 43 cents​.

  • The company reported quarterly net income of $82.77 million.

  • ChampionX Corp shares had risen by 4.9% this quarter.

FORECAST CHANGES

  • The mean earnings estimate of analysts had risen by about 5.2% in the last three months.​

  • In the last 30 days, there have been no negative revisions of earnings estimates

RECOMMENDATIONS

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "strong buy" and the breakdown of recommendations is 6 "strong buy" or "buy," no "hold" and no "sell" or "strong sell."

  • The average consensus recommendation for the oil related services and equipment peer group is "buy."

Wall Street's median 12-month price target for ChampionX Corp is $41.00

This summary was machine generated from LSEG data February 4 at 10:38 p.m. UTC. ​All figures in US dollars unless otherwise stated. data.title: New Zealand's Unemployment Rate Rises to Four-Year High — Update
data.description:
By James Glynn

SYDNEY--New Zealand's unemployment rose to its highest level in four years in the final months of last year, highlighting the extent of its economic slowdown and locking in a further significant cut in interest rates when the central bank meets later this month.

Unemployment rose to 5.1% in the fourth quarter, the highest it has been since the third quarter of 2020, when it stood at 5.2%, Stats NZ said Wednesday.

Outside of the pandemic, the jobless rate rose to its highest level since 2016.

The economy shed 32,000 jobs through calendar 2024, the largest annual fall in employment since 2009, it added.

The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has been cutting interest rates aggressively since mid-2024, with senior bank officials indicating in recent months that more will be needed to restore momentum to the economy.

A combination of soaring interest rates and a surge in the cost of living over recent years had seen New Zealand's move in and out of recession in that time.

Recent GDP growth data was far weaker than most economists had expected, putting the RBNZ on track to deliver a further 50 basis-point cut in the official cash rate on Feb. 19, taking the total reduction in the official cash rate to 175 basis points since midway through last year.

The OCR currently stands at 4.25%.

The RBNZ has also pointed to growing uncertainty around the global economic outlook, and the fact that inflation has returned to target, as key reasons to ease policy settings.

Wednesday's labor-market release should pave the way for the RBNZ to cut rates by another 50 basis points at its meeting in two weeks' time, said Abhijit Surya, economist at Capital Economics.

"And looking further ahead, we still expect the bank to eventually cut rates to 2.25%, well below the 3% terminal rate that most are predicting," he added.

The underutilization rate, which measures untapped capacity in the labor market, rose to 12.1% in the fourth quarter from 11.6% in the third quarter.

Men accounted for 85% of the annual decrease in employment, reflecting substantial falls in the male-dominated occupation groups of technicians and trades workers, and machinery operators and drivers, the data showed.

Write to James Glynn at james.glynn@wsj.com

data.title: 3M to Pay Quarterly Dividend of $0.73 a Share, Payable March 12 to Shareholders of Record on Feb. 14
Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan Buys Back 1.2 Million Shares in January
data.description:
Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan Holdings repurchased 1.2 million shares for 2.81 billion yen in January, according to a Tuesday filing on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

The buyback is part of a program approved on Nov. 6, 2024, allowing the buyback of up to 20 million shares, or 11% of outstanding stock, for a maximum of 30 billion yen.

As of Jan. 31, the company has acquired 3 million shares, spending 7.37 billion yen.

data.title: NETRAMARK PROVIDES BUSINESS UPDATE
data.description:
NETRAMARK PROVIDES BUSINESS UPDATE

Canada NewsWire

TORONTO, Feb. 4, 2025

TORONTO, Feb. 4, 2025 /CNW/ - NetraMark Holdings Inc. (the "Company" or "NetraMark") (Frankfurt: 8TV) a generative AI software leader in clinical trial analytics, is pleased to highlight recent corporate advancements; including a key leadership appointment, a major pharmaceutical collaboration, a strategic board addition, a strengthened financial position and a new marketing / investor relations engagement.

Dr. Angelico Carta Appointed as Chief Strategy Officer

As previously announced on December 11, 2024, NetraMark appointed Dr. Angelico Carta, co-founder of Worldwide Clinical Trials, as its Chief Strategy Officer. Dr. Carta brings over 35 years of experience in clinical research and pharmaceutical strategy, enhancing NetraMark's ability to expand partnerships and refine its go-to-market approach. His leadership is expected to play a critical role in advancing NetraMark's AI-driven capabilities in clinical trials and precision medicine.

Strategic Collaboration with Top 5 Pharmaceutical Company

As previously announced on December 9, 2024, NetraMark has entered into a pilot collaboration agreement with a Top 5 pharmaceutical company, as defined by market capitalization. The initiative aims to leverage NetraAI technology to uncover novel insights into patient populations, improving the client's development of treatments for autoimmune disorders. This collaboration aligns with one of the Company's core goals - validation of the technology through major collaborations and co-publishing opportunities.

P.J. Haley Joins Board of Directors

As previously announced on October 9, 2024, NetraMark welcomed P.J. Haley, Executive Vice President of Commercial at Exelixis, Inc., to its Board of Directors. With over 20 years of experience in oncology commercialization, market access, and strategic partnerships, Mr. Haley will help steer NetraMark's expansion into the oncology sector, aligning AI solutions with evolving industry needs.

$1.16 Million Raised Through Warrant and Stock Option Exercises

As previously announced on December 12, 2024, NetraMark strengthened its financial position in Q1 of this fiscal year through the exercise of warrants and stock options by their holders, raising $1,161,000. This capital infusion will support the continued development and expansion of NetraMark's AI solutions, designed to empower pharmaceutical companies with advanced insights for clinical trial success. The funding reinforces the company's ability to scale operations and drive innovation in precision medicine.

Marketing, Public and Investor Relations

NetraMark announces that it has extended the term of its original agreement ("ARU Agreement") with ARU Global Inc. ("ARU") to provide public relations services in an effort to increase public awareness of the Company. Certain services to be provided by ARU are anticipated to include "investor relations activities" under the policies of the Canadian Securities Exchange. Any materials disseminated by ARU will require the prior written approval of the Company.

The term of the ARU Agreement is extended to Mach 31, 2025. The ARU Agreement was also amended to increase compensation paid during the term to ARU, from $112,000 USD to $133,000 USD. ARU is owned by Brian Uppal and is located at 17th Floor, PH Plaza 2000 50th Street Panama City, Panama and can be reached at 507-6532-8900 or brian@aruglobalinc.com. ARU does not have any interest, directly or indirectly, in NetraMark or its securities, or any right or intent to acquire such an interest.

NetraMark also announces it has entered into an agreement with 1502656 B.C LTD. ("BC Ltd.)" to provide strategic digital media services, marketing (including awareness campaigns) and data analytical services to the Company (the "Marketing Agreement"). The term of the Marketing Agreement is for a period of six months commencing February 4, 2025. During the term of the Marketing Agreement, BC LTD. will be paid compensation equal to C$300,000. BC LTD. and its principals are arm's length to the Company. As of the date hereof, to the Company's knowledge, BC LTD. (including its directors and officers) do not own any securities of the Company. BC LTD. is located at 3849 154th Street Surrey, BC V3Z0V3, and can be reached at 604-317-2952 or nate@wagnergroup.media

About NetraAI

In contrast with other AI-based methods, NetraAI is uniquely engineered to include focus mechanisms that separate small datasets into explainable and unexplainable subsets. Unexplainable subsets are collections of patients that can lead to suboptimal overfit models and inaccurate insights due to poor correlations with the variables involved. The NetraAI uses the explainable subsets to derive insights and hypotheses (including factors that influence treatment and placebo responses, as well as adverse events) that have the potential to increase the chances of a clinical trial success. Other AI methods lack these focus mechanisms and assign every patient to a class, even when this leads to "overfitting" which drowns out critical information that could have been used to improve a trial's chance of success.

About NetraMark

NetraMark is a company focused on being a leader in the development of Generative Artificial Intelligence (Gen AI)/Machine Learning (ML) solutions targeted at the Pharmaceutical industry. Its product offering uses a novel topology-based algorithm that has the ability to parse patient data sets into subsets of people that are strongly related according to several variables simultaneously. This allows NetraMark to use a variety of ML methods, depending on the character and size of the data, to transform the data into powerfully intelligent data that activates traditional AI/ML methods. The result is that NetraMark can work with much smaller datasets and accurately segment diseases into different types, as well as accurately classify patients for sensitivity to drugs and/or efficacy of treatment.

For further details on the Company please see the Company's publicly available documents filed on the System for Electronic Document Analysis and Retrieval+ (SEDAR+).

data.title: New Zealand's Unemployment Rate Rises to Four-Year High
data.description:
By James Glynn

SYDNEY--New Zealand's unemployment rose to its highest level in four years in the final months of last year, highlighting the extent of its economic slowdown and locking in a further significant cut in interest rates when the central bank meets later this month.

Unemployment rose to 5.1% in the fourth quarter, the highest it has been since the third quarter of 2020, when it stood at 5.2%, Stats NZ said Wednesday.

The economy shed 32,000 jobs through calendar 2024, the largest annual fall in employment since the 2009, it added.

The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has been cutting interest rates aggressively since mid-2024, with senior bank officials indicating in recent months that more will be needed to restore momentum to the economy.

A combination of soaring interest rates and a surge in the cost of living over recent years had seen New Zealand's move in and out of recession in that time.

Recent GDP growth data was far weaker than most economists had expected, putting the RBNZ on track to deliver a further 50 basis-point cut in the official cash rate on Feb. 19, taking the total reduction in the official cash rate to 175 basis points since midway through last year.

The RBNZ has also pointed to growing uncertainty around the global economic outlook, and the fact that inflation has returned to target, as key reasons to ease policy settings.

The underutilization rate, which measures untapped capacity in the labor market, rose to 12.1% in the fourth quarter from 11.6% in the third quarter.

Men accounted for 85% of the annual decrease in employment, reflecting substantial falls in the male-dominated occupation groups of technicians and trades workers, and machinery operators and drivers, the data showed.

Write to James Glynn at james.glynn@wsj.com

data.title: Kelly Partners Group Posts Higher Fiscal H1 Earnings as Revenue Rises
data.description:
Kelly Partners Group Holdings reported Wednesday fiscal first-half attributable earnings of AU$0.0556 per diluted share, up from AU$0.0435 per diluted share a year earlier.

Revenue from ordinary activities for the six months ended Dec. 31, 2024, was AU$64.9 million, up from AU$52.9 million a year ago.

There were no dividends declared for the period.

data.title: 3M Raises Dividend, Authorizes $7.5B Share Repurchase Plan
data.description:
By Stephen Nakrosis

3M board raised its dividend to 73 cents per share of the company's common stock for the first quarter, up from 70 cents per share.

The new dividend, $2.92 on an annual basis, will be paid on March 12 to shareholders of record at the close of business on Feb. 14.

Based on Tuesday's closing share price of $151.68, the dividend represents a yield of about 1.9%.

3M said it has paid dividends to its shareholders without interruption for more than 100 years.

The company also said its board authorized the repurchase of up to $7.5 billion of outstanding common stock, replacing an existing repurchase program. The authorization has no pre-established closing date.

3M has a market cap of $80.94 billion, 539.74 million shares outstanding and a public float of 538.98 million.

data.title: F-Code to Acquire Ciel Zero to Boost Digital Transformation, AI Capabilities
data.description:
F-Code will acquire an 80% stake in Ciel Zero Inc. for 1.31 billion yen, aiming to strengthen its digital transformation and AI capabilities, according to a Tuesday filing on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

The deal, approved by the board on Feb. 4, is set to close on Feb. 14.

Ciel Zero, spun off from UE Corporation on Jan. 31, provides IT engineering and AI-driven solutions. F-Code expects the acquisition to enhance its technology offerings and boost profitability.

data.title: Columbia Sportswear Q4 Earnings, Sales Increase; Sets Q1 Guidance; Shares Slump After Hours
data.description:
Columbia Sportswear reported Q4 earnings late Tuesday of $1.80 per diluted share, up from $1.55 a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $1.89.

Net sales for the quarter that ended Dec. 31 was $1.10 billion, up from $1.06 billion a year earlier.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $1.08 billion.

The company said it expects Q1 earnings of $0.62 to $0.70 per diluted share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expect $0.71. The company expects net sales for the quarter of $749 million to $764 million. Analysts polled by FactSet expect $798.3 million.

For full-year 2025, the company expects earnings of $3.80 to $4.15 per diluted share on net sales of $3.40 billion to $3.47 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet expect $4.32 and $3.48 billion, respectively.

Shares of the company were 7.4% lower in after-hours activity.

data.title: PayPal Holdings, Inc. SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
PayPal Holdings, Inc., a leading global payments platform, has released its 2024 Form 10-K report, detailing significant financial growth, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces in the evolving digital payments landscape. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's performance, strategic direction, and risk management efforts.

Financial Highlights

  • Net Revenues: $31,797 million, a 7% increase compared to 2023, driven primarily by growth in total payment volume.
  • Operating Income: $5,325 million, a 6% increase due to net revenues increasing more than operating expenses.
  • Net Income (Loss): $4,147 million, a 2% decrease due to a decrease in other income (expense), net, driven primarily by net losses on strategic investments.
  • Net Income (Loss) Per Diluted Share: $3.99, a 4% increase compared to 2023.

Business Highlights

  • Revenue Segments: PayPal's transaction revenues grew by $2.0 billion, or 7%, in 2024 compared to 2023, driven primarily by increases in revenues from Braintree, core PayPal, and Venmo products and services. Braintree saw the largest increase, contributing approximately $1.3 billion to the growth.
  • Geographical Performance: Approximately 37% of PayPal's total payment volume (TPV) in 2024 was generated outside of the U.S., with significant contributions from regions such as Europe and Asia-Pacific. The company continues to expand its global reach, operating in approximately 200 markets worldwide.
  • Sales Units: PayPal processed 26.3 billion payment transactions in 2024, marking a 5% increase from 2023. The number of active accounts also grew to 434 million, a 2% increase from the previous year.
  • New Product Launches: PayPal expanded its buy now, pay later offerings in the U.S., U.K., France, Germany, and Japan through its Paidy brand, emphasizing the absence of interest or late fees in most geographies.
  • Future Outlook: PayPal aims to accelerate growth in its branded checkout business by improving user experience and expanding its value proposition for consumers and merchants. The company is also focused on increasing offline engagement through PayPal-branded debit and credit cards and building strategic partnerships to enhance customer experiences.

Strategic Initiatives

  • Receivables Portfolio Management: PayPal has entered into a multi-year agreement with a global investment firm to sell its eligible consumer installment receivables portfolio, which was amended in December 2024 to extend the commitment period to December 2026 and increase the maximum balance of loans that can be sold. This initiative is part of PayPal's strategy to manage its credit products and liquidity needs effectively.
  • Capital Management: PayPal's capital management activities included repurchasing approximately $6.0 billion of its common stock in 2024 under the stock repurchase program authorized in June 2022. As of December 31, 2024, approximately $4.9 billion remained available for future repurchases. Additionally, PayPal maintains a $5.0 billion revolving credit facility, with no borrowings outstanding as of December 31, 2024, providing significant liquidity. The company also issued fixed-rate notes with varying maturity dates, maintaining an aggregate principal amount of $10.6 billion in fixed-rate debt outstanding.
  • Future Outlook: PayPal plans to continue its focus on profitable growth, particularly in its Braintree offerings, and expects lower volume and transaction revenue growth from these offerings in 2025. The company aims to expand the availability of its credit products with capital from external sources, although there is no assurance of success. PayPal's Board of Directors authorized an additional $15.0 billion stock repurchase program in February 2025, indicating a continued commitment to returning value to shareholders.

Challenges and Risks

  • Cybersecurity and Technology Risks: The company faces significant risks from evolving cybersecurity threats, including advanced cyberattacks, ransomware, and data breaches. These threats could compromise customer data, damage reputation, and result in regulatory penalties. The company has experienced incidents in the past and anticipates future challenges in this area.
  • Business Interruptions: Natural disasters, cyberattacks, and other disruptions could impair the availability of the company's services. The increasing frequency of climate-related events poses additional risks to operations, particularly given the company's headquarters in a seismically active region.
  • Regulatory and Compliance Risks: The company is subject to extensive and evolving regulations across multiple jurisdictions, including those related to payments, data protection, and cryptocurrency. Non-compliance could lead to significant fines, operational restrictions, and reputational damage.
  • Cryptocurrency Regulation: The regulatory landscape for cryptocurrencies is rapidly changing, which could impose additional compliance costs and operational challenges. The company's involvement with stablecoins, such as PayPal USD, introduces further regulatory scrutiny and potential liabilities.
  • Operational Risks: The company relies on third-party providers for critical services, which introduces risks related to service disruptions and compliance failures. Any failure by these third parties could negatively impact the company's operations and reputation.
  • Market Risks: The company faces intense competition in the global payments industry, which is characterized by rapid technological changes and evolving consumer preferences. Failure to innovate or adapt to these changes could harm the company's competitive position.
  • Management's Discussion and Analysis: Management acknowledges the challenges posed by regulatory changes and competitive pressures. The company is investing in technology upgrades and compliance measures to mitigate these risks. Strategic partnerships and acquisitions are also being considered to enhance market position and operational resilience.
  • Market Risk Disclosures: The company is exposed to foreign exchange rate fluctuations, which could adversely affect financial results. The management is implementing hedging strategies to mitigate these risks and ensure financial stability.

SEC Filing: PayPal Holdings, Inc. [ PYPL ] - 10-K - Feb. 04, 2025

data.title: FMC Shares Drop on Weak Outlook as Customers Cut Inventory
data.description:
By Paul Ziobro

Shares of FMC plunged after the agricultural services company forecast a sharp drop in profit and sales stemming from customers cutting inventory levels around the world and cautious purchase patterns by end users.

Shares fell 17.1% to $44.81 in late trading, after closing the regular trading session at $54.04. Through Tuesday's close, the stock had been up about 11.2% over the last year.

FMC Chief Executive Pierre Brondeau said that volume growth in the fourth quarter fell below its expectations as customers in many countries aimed to hold significantly less inventory than they have historically.

The challenges will continue into the current quarter, where it projects sales between $750 million and $800 million, a drop of 16% at the midpoint compared to a year ago. Analysts were looking for revenue of $957 million, according to FactSet.

Adjusted per-share earnings are expected between 5 cents and 15 cents. Analysts were looking for 77 cents.

The company expects volume to improve over the course of the year, with an increase in growth portfolio sales offsetting weaker demand in the channel.

But its full-year forecast also came in short of expectations. FMC expects adjusted per-share earnings between $3.26 and $3.70 on revenue between $4.15 billion and $4.35 billion.

Analysts were looking for per-share earnings of $4.35 on revenue of $4.39 billion.

The view came after FMC reported that revenue rose 7% in the fourth quarter. It also swung to a loss, primarily tied to tax incentives in the prior-year period granted to its Swiss subsidiaries. Adjusted earnings of $1.79 a share, meanwhile, topped analyst expectations for $1.60 a share.

Write to Paul Ziobro at paul.ziobro@wsj.com

data.title: AMD's AI Revenue Jumps in 4Q, But Misses Estimates — Update
data.description:
By Connor Hart

Advanced Micro Devices posted higher quarterly revenue thanks to significant growth in its data-center business, but results failed to impress Wall Street, sending the stock lower.

The Santa Clara, Calif., chip maker said Tuesday that sales across its data-center division--which includes its artificial-intelligence chips--jumped 69%, to $3.9 billion, primarily due to the ramp of its Instinct chip. Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting data-center revenue of $4.14 billion.

Shares fell 3.8%, to $114.91, after the bell. The stock is down 29% in the past year, as some analysts and investors have found the AI positioning of its competitors, including Nvidia, as more compelling.

Overall revenue increased 24%, to $7.66 billion, ahead of the $7.53 billion that analysts had modeled.

AMD's client, or personal-computing, revenue rose 58%, to $2.3 billion, driven by what the company called strong demand for its Ryzen processors. The gain was slightly offset by the company's gaming unit, where sales fell 59%, to $563 million, and its embedded segment, down 13%, to $923 million.

During its quarter ended Dec. 28, the company posted a profit of $482 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $667 million, or 41 cents a share, a year earlier. Adjusted per-share earnings came in at $1.09, narrowly beating the $1.08 that analysts polled by FactSet were expecting.

Chief Executive Lisa Su said there are clear opportunities for the company to continue growing in 2025, citing its product portfolio and growing demand for high-performance and adaptive computing.

For the current quarter, AMD guided for revenue between $6.8 billion and $7.4 billion, the midpoint of which beat the $7 billion that analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast.

The company has benefited from robust AI demand, supplying chips used to create and deploy tools that produce human-like text, images and video, but its non-AI offerings have stalled growth. As part of a shift in AMD's broader business strategy towards AI, it said in November that it would reduce its global workforce by 4%, or about 1,040 jobs.

Write to Connor Hart at connor.hart@wsj.com

data.title: Western Union Q4 Adjusted Earnings, Revenue Increase; Sets 2025 Guidance
data.description:
Western Union reported Q4 adjusted diluted earnings late Tuesday of $0.40 per share, up from $0.37 a year earlier.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $0.42.

Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 was $1.06 billion, up from $1.05 billion a year ago.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $1.03 billion.

The company set its full-year 2025 guidance of adjusted earnings between $1.75 to $1.85 per share on revenue of $4.12 billion to $4.22 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expect EPS of $1.81 and revenue of $4.20 billion.
